comments.commentBody: I agree with you. I really can't understand how it is "free speech" to insult or satirise another person, or their religion, or culture, especially if it is not mine, or in this case western. like, why would one provoke others like that? I find it painful to be treated like that and for the perpetrator to claim that they have free speech to do so. i think we need to be empathetic to others. it is not just our free speech that matters. it is also how our free speech treats and affects others. i come from Uganda, and i think most people there dont agree with this understanding of free speech either. we love to be free and speak freely, but when it comes to insulting others we try to be more respectful. to me this view of free speech that leaves others in pain is quite selfish, it disregards others in the community.

You are both suggesting censorship.  Where does it end?  People's feelings are hurt, ban that story, take down that cartoon.  We can't satirize or make fun of the pope, he might cry or some person who likes the pope might be upset.  How utterly ridiculous.  No expression except pablum: safe, sanitized and worthless.

@Frea and Latha, you both have the luxury of living in democratic countries where free expression is allowed. Try moving to a country where free speech/ expression is not permitted. I have family and friends who live or lived in Communist or other oppressive countries. Then you will understand why it is important.

Cant everybody just back off ,no more satirical cartoons no more hate speeches against Muslims.Dont give these terrorists ammunitions to attack.There was an appeal by the Egyption president to the Immams to radicaly bring some revolutionary changes in the religion to save Islam.The western countries should leave the Muslim countries to sort out the issues by themselves and get the hell out of ME.Why humilate people. I know my comment is going to invite a lot of barages but we in India stay in a multicultural society and are very carful about ethnicity.We have been victims of terrorism long since the West even heard about but look at the restraint we have maintained.
let me be the example, thanks!

One trick I've found that helps to prevent buildup and waste: If I'm going to freeze something, it's going to be in ready-to-use form. Prechopped herbs, precooked meatballs, preassembled lasagne, muffins and banana or zucchini breads.  I've found that if the freezer is a fast-food place, the food will get eaten.  I rarely freeze raw meat for this reason.
A bit more research would've helped this article. How many take out restaurants will financially qualify for the ban?
Econ 101 - The limited ban will create a near-term market advantage for alternatives.  As the market grows those alternatives will become cheaper and supplant foam anyway.
If this ban makes sense -- and I think it does -- why include potential exemptions for nonprofits and businesses with less than $500,000 in annual revenue.
Excellent. Thank you Mr. Mayor.
if you're ordering delivery and the food arrives luke warm, run it through the microwave for a few seconds. Or learn how to cook.

[[How are the police and other emergency crews going to feed themselves on a busy shift. Many are patrons of small food outlets that offer a fresh hot meal.]]

Busy shifts? Cops aren't writing tickets or making arrests, so how is this a problem for them? Based on recent behavior, they can all schedule sit down meals at Zagat rated establishments.
Air Marshal, apparently you need to reread the article. This effort started with that ultra-leftist Michael Bloomberg.

Excellent choice, and a great suggestion!  As of tonight, the Badgers are 15-1, having lost only to Duke.  Plus 7-footer Frank Kaminsky can dance (!), Vitto Brown can sing like an angel, and Nigel (Burgundy) Hayes is the natural successor to Stephen Colbert.  Wildly entertaining group of kids.  They are Mad City, though and through.  Go Bucky!
France invited them in and did nothing as they grew increasingly radical.  It is a shame that the victims had to be precisely those Frenchmen who were courageous enough to stand up for the West.
This article nowhere says that the client contended that that the lawyer filed an appeal without the client's permission. You are assuming something not in evidence.

The article assumes that the lawyers originally appointed had been replaced by the new attorneys.  And Justice Alito was trying to determine which set of attorneys, in fact, had the client's permission to represent him since both sets were claiming that they were the proper attorneys.

With respect to whether the record would deal with legal representation, it clearly would in a case where the client was contending that the lawyer was pursuing an appeal without the client's permission.  That is really all Justice Alito was trying to ascertain given that that the lawyers representing Mr. Christeson were contending they were the attorneys authorized to represent him rather than the school of law attorneys.

Great idea! Over here you can always buy cloth bags. I have a whole supply and put everything in them. If they become dirty, I stick them into the washing machine with my other washables. Of course, for meat or other goods I have small plastic containers; the salespeople here accept the way many others like me do things. I guess Europe is more open to these changes than is the USA, where I got very offended looks from cashiers when I said that I did not need a plastic bag for my purchases as I had a cloth bag.
Plastic shopping bags are widely used in NYC as trash can liners.   If they were banned, people would just have to buy them in order to have something to put their trash in.

Yes. I found that out when plastic bags were banned from the supermarkets here. I use to use the ones I got at the supermarket  to line my kitchen garbage bin. I now buy plastic bags to use in the kitchen. I have no problem bringing my own bags to shop- some fold so small they fit into my purse. What we need for the kitchen type bags and all those plastic containers that products come in are biodegradable replacements that offer the same good benefits as plastics but will brake down in the landfills without harmful effects and be cost effective. It will have to come by a combination of legislation and innovation. Maybe there could be a big cash prize for a viable environmentally friendly replacement- a whole new industry could arise.
Next up: Ban plastic shopping bags. Bring your own bags.
Erm, I'm pretty sure we use plastic and foam because it is cheaper.  It has long been known that given the choice of "paper or plastic" the better choice was paper.

The margarine companies bought a lot of ads to convince people to switch without ever studying the actual long-term impacts.  The plastic industry advertized the idea that they were saving trees but my third grade science from the 1960's had already taught me about decomposition.  There was no cycle, only a profitable-to-some deviation from common sense.

Andre - plastic is only recyclable to a finite degree. Eventually plastic cannot be recycled anymore and will go to a landfill where it sits forever. Every piece of plastic we've ever used will exist forever in some form. That's a lot of plastic.
butter or margarine.  we changed to plastic and foam to save paper and trees.  now we are going back to cardboard and the cycle is complete

"I have to say that such a policy does have a measurable effect on the environment"

Really. What is that effect and how did you measure it.

The city of Boulder, including organizations like the University of Colorado-Boulder do have a strong zero-tolerance policy for foam food containers, and I have to say that such a policy does have a measurable effect on the environment. It's nice to see a much bigger city like NY following the People's Republic!
where?

Sorry, I disagree with that.  If I'm travelling, and want to pick up a drink at my next gas stop, I don't want to be forced to drink soda instead of water.  Much better to add a deposit to all drink containers, so the majority will be returned.
California has banned selling single use water bottles. We should too.
Exactly.  Makes no sense.  Though some of those vendors gross more than that

You may want to reread the conditions for those exemptions, and ask yourself if an administration that has already used its executive discretion to decide to apply this rule will be inclined to use its discretion to make it look visibly toothless to every New Yorker passing a halal cart. Also, it is 500K in revenue, not profit. That is not that much these days. It is a low-margin business.

"Nonprofits and businesses with less than $500,000 in annual revenue can apply for exemptions".
Well at least the food carts and other street vendors, chinese and burrito take outs, and the local deli are safe from this environmentally friendly upgrade.

It is important to adress the post 9-11 world rather than see this current incident as a "French" problem. United by ideology, terrorists are striking all over the world, on many continents, and believing they do it with honor, and with divine support. This could be an opportunity for not eye-for-an-eye retaliation, but for global consideration of why this is happening and how to respond.

I think that's unfair, and un-factual, and I say that as someone whose Armenian family were killed by Muslim Turks in 1918. There are people of the Muslim religion all over the world who are comparable in their secular approach and tolerant attitude to your average secular Christian. This is exactly the struggle going on now in Turkey, Egypt, Tunisia and many other Muslim countries. Many of the world's Muslims live in traditional societies where western individualism, consumer culture and diversity have yet to dissolve the bonds of orthodoxy and obedience. Even disenchanted French born Muslims hear the call of this toxic, militant brand. But of more than a billion Muslims in the world, we don't find all are terrorists do we.

Thank everyone who has worked to this end in New York. Your children and grandchildren thank you.
I am dizzy happy that the foam will no longer perform the static electricity game.

Actually, I carry a stainless-steel tin with me to carry leftovers with me from restaurants and to get takeout. It's leakproof and spillproof, and restauranteurs love me.

I seriously never order delivery because of all the wasteful disposable packaging.
We do the same things --take our own container to restaurants,don't order in.  One tiny step for the world, one big step for the city!

When I travel I refuse my food and drinks to be in foam containers. They leach chemicals into your food. Do Not put foam containers and cups in the microwave! Carcinogen chemicals leach. Banning them is a win win- for the environment and for your health. Substitute containers work just as well.

Stu Freeman,
The Keystone Cops bit was very good. I can almost hear the music.

I knew it would be only a matter of minutes before the Republicans tried to take credit for the good economic news (as well as for the fact that the Russian economy has tanked lately and for the sun having come up every morning since Election Day). As for the Keystone Pipeline it seems entirely logical that its most ardent supporters would be the Keystone Cops.

But there is truly no durable consensus between even the "lovely" Muslims living among us, with whom one nominally may be "friends," and the civilized world. Vocabulary, usage, and idiom of the Islamic cohort do not translate into English, French, German, Italian, or Spanish.

Peaceful Muslims have not condemned Islamofascism and terrorism, particularly not through their organizations such as CAIR here in the U.S.

Instead, all too frequently one reads ludicrous counter-accusations of "state terrorism" leveled against the U.S. and Israel by Moslems and their fellow travelers. As a society we cling to a paternalistic fiction, believing that Muslims, like other ethnics before them, will willingly amalgamate with Western society in the "melting pot." They will not. They are different:

The Islamic tradition has not provided a meaningful response. Islam has not shunned terrorists, they and their life-support networks have not been ostracized by mainstream Moslem society.
That is just not true, I live in Israel and have Moslems israel I friends and work partners, the all say....This is NOT our religion!

You do know it is fairly common practice to cover over sections of landfills with foam - often about 6 inches - to keep the detritus from blowing around as the fill is occurring.

The most valuable thing in a landfill is space, so the use of foam makes sense, because it packs down well under the pressure of the tractors moving and grading the trash. In most landfills, paper products at 25% are about twice the volume of plastic (around 10%) - neither will degrade even if they are biodegradable because once filled, the landfills are capped and sealed against water and air infiltration.

In 400 years or so, the country will be dealing with our current landfills as either "toxic dump sites" in need of remediation, or "valuable sources of raw metals, paper, and plastic."

Except none of your reasons apply here.

The terrorists were born in France; grew up orphaned. Never left France until one of them wanted to join the war in Syria in 2005 and was sent to prison for it.
He appeared contrite. But it seems he was just a sleeper.
